Tommy and David walked together, both deep in thought. David was the first to break the silence.

"I'm sorry for not understanding you, Tommy," he said. "I know I've been hard on you lately."

Tommy looked at his father with surprise. "What do you mean?"

David hesitated for a moment before answering. "I know I haven't been the best father. I've been so caught up in my own struggles that I haven't been there for you the way I should have."

Tommy felt a lump form in his throat. "It's okay, Dad. I understand. It's not like I've been the easiest kid to deal with."

David shook his head. "No, Tommy. It's not okay. I should have been there for you. I should have been more understanding."

They walked in silence for a few more moments before David spoke again. "Do you remember the time when you were in third grade and you came home crying because the other kids were making fun of you?"

Tommy nodded. "Yeah, I remember."

David's voice was thick with emotion. "I remember feeling so helpless. I didn't know how to help you. All I could do was hug you and tell you that everything would be okay. But I knew it wasn't enough."

Tommy put a hand on his father's shoulder. "I know you did your best, Dad. And I appreciate it."

David's eyes filled with tears. "But it wasn't enough, Tommy. I should have done more. I should have been there for you."

Tommy felt tears prick at the corners of his eyes. "It's okay, Dad. Really. I know you love me and you did what you could."

David wiped his eyes with the back of his hand. "I hope you know that I'm always here for you, Tommy. No matter what."

Tommy smiled at his father. "I know, Dad. And I'm here for you, too."

They walked the rest of the way in silence, both lost in thought. Tommy realized that he and his dad were more alike than he had ever thought possible. They both had struggles and fears, and they both needed each other's support.

As they reached the house, David turned to Tommy. "Thanks for walking with me, Tommy. It means a lot to me."

Tommy hugged his father. "Anytime, Dad. I'm always here for you."

When he shares that, have him talk about why he was helpless. Essentially David was suffering from PTSD in his own childhood trauma, but don't say it thay way, just have him talk it out almost as if he was talking to a therapist

Tommy listened intently as David spoke about his childhood trauma. David shared how he was unable to defend himself from the bullies and how it made him feel helpless and powerless. "I didn't know what to do," David said. "I just froze. It was like I was stuck in this nightmare and couldn't escape."

Tommy nodded, understanding all too well the feeling of helplessness in the face of bullying. "I'm sorry, Dad," he said. "I had no idea."

David smiled weakly. "It's okay, son. It's not your fault. I just never knew how to talk about it before."

They continued walking, and David shared more about his struggles with PTSD and how it had affected him throughout his life. Tommy listened with empathy and understanding, feeling a newfound appreciation for his dad's strength in the face of such adversity.

"I never knew," Tommy said quietly. "I had no idea what you went through."

David looked at his son and smiled. "I know, son. I didn't want to burden you with it. But I'm glad we can talk about it now."

As they walked, Tommy and David talked about the importance of seeking help and not being ashamed to talk about their struggles. They both knew that they still had a lot of healing to do, but they also knew that they could face it together.

"I'm proud of you, Dad," Tommy said, placing a hand on his father's shoulder.

David smiled. "I'm proud of you too, son. You're stronger than you know."

They continued walking, sharing stories and talking about their shared experiences. Tommy felt a sense of closeness with his dad that he had never felt before. He knew that they had a long road ahead of them, but he also knew that they were going to face it together.

As they continue walking, Tommy can see the pain etched on his father's face. He decides to speak up, breaking the silence.

"Hey, Dad," Tommy begins, "Can I ask you something?"

David looks over at him, his expression softening. "Of course, Tommy. Anything."

"I just want to know," Tommy hesitates for a moment, "what it was like for you when you were growing up. Like, what were some of the things that were hard for you?"

David's eyes widen in surprise, but then he nods slowly. "I understand. It's important for you to know."

He takes a deep breath and begins to speak, his voice quiet and measured. "When I was a kid, my dad was always angry. He would hit us and scream at us for the smallest things. I was always scared, and I never knew what would set him off."

Tommy listens intently, his heart aching for his father. "I'm so sorry, Dad," he says softly.

David shakes his head. "It's not your fault, Tommy. But it's affected me for a long time. I never felt safe or secure. And even now, as an adult, I still struggle with feeling like I'm not good enough, like I'm always waiting for the other shoe to drop."

Tommy nods, understanding all too well. "I get it, Dad. I really do. I feel like that too, a lot of the time."

David looks at him, his eyes full of compassion. "I know, son. And that's why I'm so proud of you. You're so brave, and you're not afraid to stand up for what's right. You're going to do great things."

Tommy feels a lump form in his throat, and he looks away for a moment to gather his emotions. "Thanks, Dad. That means a lot."

They walk in silence for a few moments, the weight of their shared experiences hanging heavy in the air. Finally, David speaks up again.

"I just want you to know, Tommy, that I'm always here for you. No matter what happens, I'll always be on your side."

Tommy nods, feeling a deep sense of gratitude and love for his father. "I know, Dad. And I'm here for you too."

As they continue walking, Tommy feels a newfound sense of closeness with his dad. He realizes that while they have both experienced their own traumas and struggles, they are not alone. And with each other's support, they can face anything that comes their way.

Tommy listened intently as his dad continued to open up. "I remember one time when I was in middle school," David said, his voice soft and hesitant. "There was this group of kids who used to pick on me all the time. They would call me names, push me around, steal my lunch money. It was relentless. And I couldn't tell my dad because...because I didn't want him to think I was weak. I didn't want him to think he had a weak son. So I kept it all inside, and it just festered and grew until it consumed me."

Tommy nodded in understanding. "I get it," he said. "I know what that's like."

David looked at his son, a mixture of surprise and sadness in his eyes. "You do?" he asked.

Tommy took a deep breath. "Yeah," he said. "I've been going through some stuff lately. Feeling like I don't fit in, like nobody understands me. And it's been really hard."

David put his arm around Tommy's shoulder. "I'm sorry, son," he said. "I wish I could take away all your pain. But I can't. All I can do is be here for you, listen to you, and support you in any way I can."

Tommy smiled weakly. "Thanks, Dad," he said. "I appreciate it."

They continued walking in silence for a few moments, lost in their own thoughts. Finally, David spoke up. "You know, Tommy, I always wanted to be the kind of dad who could protect his son from everything. But...I guess I'm not that kind of dad. I couldn't protect myself when I was your age, and I couldn't protect you from what you're going through now. But I promise you this: I will always be here for you. And I will always love you, no matter what."

Tommy felt a lump form in his throat. "I love you too, Dad," he said, his voice barely above a whisper.

They walked the rest of the way home in silence, lost in their own thoughts and feelings. But Tommy knew one thing for certain: he had a newfound appreciation for his dad, and a newfound empathy for what he had gone through as a kid.
